Abyssal Firestorm Surge (7-8).name: Abyssal Firestorm Surge (7-8)
Abyssal Firestorm Surge (7-8).descriptionHazard: High winds and forest fires intensified by Abyssal energy batters everything in the surge's path.
Abyssal Firestorm Surge (7-8).disable: @Check[type:arcana|dc:27|name:Redirect the Storm Surge|traits:rare,fire,environmental,hazard,magical], @Check[type:nature|dc:27|name:Redirect the Storm Surge|traits:rare,fire,environmental,hazard,magical], @Check[type:occultism|dc:27|name:Redirect the Storm Surge|traits:rare,fire,environmental,hazard,magical], or @Check[type:religion|dc:27|name:Redirect the Storm Surge|traits:rare,fire,environmental,hazard,magical] (trained) to redirect the storm surge or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (4th level, counteract DC 23) to nullify it.

Abyssal Firestorm Surge (9-10).name: Abyssal Firestorm Surge (9-10)
Abyssal Firestorm Surge (9-10).descriptionHazard: High winds and forest fires intensified by Abyssal energy batters everything in the surge's path.

Ancient Ooze Pit.name: Ancient Ooze Pit
Ancient Ooze Pit.descriptionHazard: A trap door covers a pit that is 10 feet square and 10 feet deep. An acidic mass that was once a gelatinous cube lies at the bottom.
Ancient Ooze Pit.reset: Creatures can still fall into the trap, but the trapdoor must be reset manually for the trap to become hidden again. The remains of the burst ooze seep into the ground, and the trap functions as a normal @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.hazards.Actor.BHq5wpQU8hQEke8D]{Hidden Pit}.

Awakened Ball Python.name: Awakened Ball Python
Awakened Ball Python.publicNotes:
This nonvenomous snake's name comes from its tendency to curl into a ball when frightened, though most people know it for its hunting tactic of coiling around prey and crushing victims with its powerful muscles. Nonetheless, brave herpetologists sometimes keep ball pythons as pets.

Snakes come in an array of forms, from jungle-dwelling constrictors that wrap around their prey to venomous vipers with deadly bites. Regardless, all snakes consume their prey whole by unhinging their jaws and using powerful muscles to move the food down their throats and into their stomachs.

Awakened Giant Chameleon.name: Awakened Giant Chameleon
Awakened Giant Chameleon.publicNotes: Giant chameleons are legendary for their ability to change their skin color in response to their surroundings. Their eyes are capable of peering in different directions independently, making them almost as difficult to sneak up on as they are to notice in the first place.

Awakened Giant Frilled Lizard.name: Awakened Giant Frilled Lizard
Awakened Giant Frilled Lizard.publicNotes:
Found in warm and tropical forests and savannas, these immense lizards are a deadly threat to the unsuspecting traveler. When they aren't sleeping or stalking prey, giant frilled lizards bask in the sunlight for hours at a time. Explorers sometimes mistakenly think them related to dragons due to their large size, elaborate neck frills (which, when displayed in a show of aggression and dominance, can be mistaken for wings), and ferocious hissing vocalizations used to frighten away creatures too large to eat.

A giant frilled lizard's primary food sources are oversized arthropods and other invertebrates, but it won't hesitate to augment its diet with vertebrates, including other lizards, monkeys, and just about anything it can fit into its mouth-even humanoids. Although capable of short bursts of speed, a giant frilled lizard normally lies perfectly still while hunting, hoping to ambush its prey.

Lizards have a wide range of appearances and abilities, but most share a basic reptilian shape-long tails, wide toothy mouths, and four legs. While a few species are capable of movement on two legs for short periods of time, most are strictly quadrupedal. The three species presented here represent the most common and well-known of the larger species.

Awakened Megalania.name: Awakened Megalania
Awakened Megalania.publicNotes: Megalanias, like their smaller cousins the giant monitor lizards, strike fast and use their powerful bite to grip their prey. They prefer to swallow their prey whole rather than risk others getting a bite of a hard-won meal.

Bloody Vortex (3-4).name: Bloody Vortex (3-4)
Bloody Vortex (3-4).disable: Slay Silaqui, or @Check[type:thievery|dc:17|traits:action:disable-a-device] (trained) to pry the gem out of Silaqui followed by disrupting the gem's power by either breaking it (AC 15, Hardness 5, HP 25, BT 13) or using @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (2nd level; counteract DC 15)
Bloody Vortex (3-4).routine:
All creatures within 40 feet of the vortex except Silaqui are drawn toward it. They must attempt either a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:14] save or an @Check[type:athletics|dc:14|traits:action:swim] check to Swim with a DC of 14, with the following results.

Success The creature is not moved.

Failure The creature is moved 10 feet closer to the center of the vortex. If this causes the creature to reach the center square of the vortex, they are exposed to Consuming Maelstrom.

Critical Failure As failure, except the creature is moved 20 feet closer to the center of the vortex.

Bloody Vortex (5-6).name: Bloody Vortex (5-6)
Bloody Vortex (5-6).descriptionHazard: A bloody vortex violently draining into a crack of raw elemental energy, fueled by the curse of a sea devil oracle.
Bloody Vortex (5-6).disable: Slay Silaqui, or @Check[type:thievery|dc:20|traits:action:disable-a-device] (trained) to pry the gem out of Silaqui followed by disrupting the gem's power by either breaking it (AC 18, Hardness 10, HP 45, BT 23) or using @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (2nd level; counteract DC 19)
Bloody Vortex (5-6).routine:
All creatures within 40 feet of the vortex except Silaqui are drawn toward it. They must attempt either a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:17] save or an @Check[type:athletics|dc:17|traits:action:swim] check to Swim with a DC of 17, with the following results.

Success The creature is not moved.

Failure The creature is moved 10 feet closer to the center of the vortex. If this causes the creature to reach the center square of the vortex, they are exposed to Consuming Maelstrom.

Critical Failure As failure, except the creature is moved 20 feet closer to the center of the vortex.

Brittle Skeletal Horse.name: Brittle Skeletal Horse
Brittle Skeletal Horse.publicNotes:
Skeletal horses are sometimes used as mounts by other undead or monsters.

Made from bones held together by foul necromancy, skeletons are among the most common types of undead, found haunting old dungeons and forgotten cemeteries.

Chaotic Door (1-2).name: Chaotic Door (1-2)
Chaotic Door (1-2).descriptionHazard: The frame splinters as the door flings open, the force hitting those nearby.
Chaotic Door (1-2).disable: @Check[type:athletics|dc:17|name:Hold the Door Shut|traits:chaotic,hazard,magical,trap] (trained) to hold the door shut against the force, or @Check[type:thievery|dc:18|name:Relieve Door Pressure|traits:chaotic,hazard,magical,trap] (trained) to deftly relieve pressure from the door.

Chaotic Door (3-4).name: Chaotic Door (3-4)
Chaotic Door (3-4).descriptionHazard: The frame splinters as the door flings open, the force hitting those nearby.
Chaotic Door (3-4).disable: @Check[type:athletics|dc:20|name:Hold the Door Shut|traits:chaotic,hazard,magical,trap] (trained) to hold the door shut against the force, or @Check[type:thievery|dc:21|name:Relieve Door Pressure|traits:chaotic,hazard,magical,trap] (trained) to deftly relieve pressure from the door.

Churning Lava (1-2).name: Churning Lava (1-2)
Churning Lava (1-2).descriptionHazard: The equilibrium of the brown mold and lava river is disturbed, creating bubbles of molten stone that burst and spew burning debris.
Churning Lava (1-2).disable: @Check[type:nature|dc:14|name:Clear mold] or @Check[type:survival|dc:14|name:Clear mold] or @Check[type:thievery|dc:17|name:Clear mold] to clear your square and all adjacent squares of the mold; the churning lava does not target creatures in cleared squares with its spatter attack, but the hazard is not destroyed until every square has been cleared of mold.
Churning Lava (1-2).reset: If not completely destroyed, the mold spreads to one additional square within 10 feet of lava each day until it fully regenerates and regains its state of equilibrium. If every square is cleaned of mold, the hazard is destroyed.
Churning Lava (1-2).routine: (1 action) On the its initiative, the churning lava targets a random creature in the area with a ranged spatter attack as a magma bubble bursts.

Churning Lava (3-4).name: Churning Lava (3-4)
Churning Lava (3-4).descriptionHazard: The equilibrium of the brown mold and lava river is disturbed, creating bubbles of molten stone that burst and spew burning debris.
Churning Lava (3-4).disable: @Check[type:nature|dc:17|name:Clear mold] or @Check[type:survival|dc:17|name:Clear mold] or @Check[type:thievery|dc:20|name:Clear mold] to clear your square and all adjacent squares of the mold; the churning lava does not target creatures in cleared squares with its spatter attack, but the hazard is not destroyed until every square has been cleared of mold.
Churning Lava (3-4).reset: If not completely destroyed, the mold spreads to one additional square within 10 feet of lava each day until it fully regenerates and regains its state of equilibrium. If every square is cleaned of mold, the hazard is destroyed.
Churning Lava (3-4).routine: (1 action) On the its initiative, the churning lava targets a random creature in the area with a ranged spatter attack as a magma bubble bursts.

Clouded Quartz (5-6).name: Clouded Quartz (5-6)
Clouded Quartz (5-6).publicNotes:
Insatiable scavengers stalking the eternal gloom of the Darklands, cavern trolls consume all in their path-even rocks and minerals when more nourishing sustenance is scarce. These rocky goliaths can tunnel through stone with their iron-sharp claws.

Cavern trolls rarely venture to the surface world, for they have a debilitating vulnerability to sunlight that petrifies them on sustained contact. Unlike common trolls, cavern trolls can regenerate wounds dealt by fire. The crystalline nature of their skin, however, permits sonic attacks to neutralize their signature regeneration.

As cavern trolls age, their flinty skin becomes studded with small crystals and stones of various composition. Paragons of their kind have toothy maws replete with large, crystalline fangs. A typical cavern troll stands 14 feet in height and weighs about 2,000 pounds.

Clouded Quartz (7-8).name: Clouded Quartz (7-8)
Clouded Quartz (7-8).publicNotes:
Insatiable scavengers stalking the eternal gloom of the Darklands, cavern trolls consume all in their path-even rocks and minerals when more nourishing sustenance is scarce. These rocky goliaths can tunnel through stone with their iron-sharp claws.

Cavern trolls rarely venture to the surface world, for they have a debilitating vulnerability to sunlight that petrifies them on sustained contact. Unlike common trolls, cavern trolls can regenerate wounds dealt by fire. The crystalline nature of their skin, however, permits sonic attacks to neutralize their signature regeneration.

As cavern trolls age, their flinty skin becomes studded with small crystals and stones of various composition. Paragons of their kind have toothy maws replete with large, crystalline fangs. A typical cavern troll stands 14 feet in height and weighs about 2,000 pounds.

Cobbleswarm (B5).name: Cobbleswarm (B5)
Cobbleswarm (B5).publicNotes:
Cobble mites resemble squarish stones a few inches across with mouths like split geodes. Though indolent and harmless alone, they're dangerous in large groups.

Busy road builders might unknowingly use cobble mites in construction.

Collapsing Cabinet (1-2).name: Collapsing Cabinet (1-2)
Collapsing Cabinet (1-2).descriptionHazard:
Fluids from leaking beakers have eaten nearly through the supports holding up this cabinet.

This Broken Threshold for this trap is 5, not 10.
Collapsing Cabinet (1-2).disable: @Check[type:thievery|dc:15|name:Support Cabinet|traits:mechanical,trap] (trained) to gently place something under the cabinet to support its weight.

Collapsing Cabinet (3-4).name: Collapsing Cabinet (3-4)
Collapsing Cabinet (3-4).descriptionHazard:
Fluids from leaking beakers have eaten nearly through the supports holding up this cabinet.

This Broken Threshold for this trap is 10, not 20.
Collapsing Cabinet (3-4).disable: @Check[type:thievery|dc:18|name:Support Cabinet|traits:mechanical,trap] (trained) to gently place something under the cabinet to support its weight.

Collapsing Ice.name: Collapsing Ice
Collapsing Ice.descriptionHazard: The ice here is weak and collapses under the weight of a Small or larger creature.
Collapsing Ice.disable: 2 @Check[type:crafting|dc:19|name:Create Ice Brace] to create a makeshift device to brace the ice.

Collapsing Ramp (7-8).name: Collapsing Ramp (7-8)
Collapsing Ramp (7-8).descriptionHazard: Abyssal fire hits the stone beneath the ramp, causing a 15-foot-long section of it to collapse.
Collapsing Ramp (7-8).disable: @Check[type:crafting|dc:28] (expert) to stabilize the masonry. Each attempt takes 2 actions.

Collapsing Ramp (9-10).name: Collapsing Ramp (9-10)
Collapsing Ramp (9-10).descriptionHazard: Abyssal fire hits the stone beneath the ramp, causing a 15-foot-long section of it to collapse.
Collapsing Ramp (9-10).disable: @Check[type:crafting|dc:31] (expert) to stabilize the masonry. Each attempt takes 2 actions.

Commoner (PFS 2-13).name: Commoner (PFS 2-13)
Commoner (PFS 2-13).publicNotes:
Though not every commoner is downtrodden, many live hard lives of toil as they work to keep their families fed and housed in relative comfort. While many commoners are just simple folks who keep to themselves, sometimes commoners rebel, either rising up to face their oppressors or persuaded or even duped into joining nefarious plans and criminal conspiracies. Commoners benefit from power in numbers, and a crowd of commoners can accomplish a great deal more than their rulers often expect.

Unfortunately, every society has people living on its fringes. While good communities work to grant aid and respite to their downtrodden, sometimes-due to economic downturn, famine, or war-the ranks of the less fortunate exceed the community's capacity to support them. In heartless neutral and evil societies, poverty is seen as an inevitability that can never be truly eradicated, or even worse, as a tool to be manipulated for political gain.

Daughter Of Cocytus Enforcer.allSavesBonus: +1 circumstance to all saves vs. traps

Disciple of Urxehl (7-8).allSavesBonus: +1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic

Dragon's Death (1-2).name: Dragon's Death (1-2)
Dragon's Death (1-2).descriptionHazard: The pile of bones transforms into a Large silver dragon, while the PCs appear to transform into dark, shadowy figures of alien physique. The dragon's flesh appears to slowly dissolve into lines of black smoke, which trail away toward the PCs and appear to be absorbed into their bodies. Once the dragon is stripped of flesh, its skeleton explodes in a shower of bone fragments.
Dragon's Death (1-2).disable: @Check[type:religion|dc:20|name:Exorcise the Spirit|traits:haunt] (trained) to exorcise the spirit (two actions), or @Check[type:diplomacy|dc:23|name:Calm the Spirit|traits:haunt] (trained) to calm the spirit momentarily (two actions).
Dragon's Death (1-2).reset: 1 minute, as the bone fragments slowly move back into a neat pile with the skull on top.
Dragon's Death (1-2).routine:
Trigger A creature comes within 15 feet of the dragon skull

Effect All living creatures within 20 feet of the nest are peppered with bone shards and take @Damage[(2d10+7)[slashing]] damage (@Check[type:reflex|dc:20|basic:true|name:Dragon's Death|traits:haunt,divine,necromancy] save).

On a critical failure, the creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Blinded} for [[/br 1d4 #hours]]{1d4 hours}.

Drandlesticks (7-8).descriptionHazard: Enchanted caltrops blend in with the surrounding masonry.

Drandlesticks (9-10).name: Drandlesticks (9-10)
Drandlesticks (9-10).descriptionHazard: Enchanted caltrops blend in with the surrounding masonry.

Duergar Raider.name: Duergar Raider
Duergar Raider.allSavesBonus: +2 status to all saves vs. magic

Electric Lock Rune.name: Electric Lock Rune
Electric Lock Rune.descriptionHazard: An invisible rune imprinted on a chest's lock releases a powerful electrical discharge.
Electric Lock Rune.disable: @Check[type:thievery|dc:20|name:Scratch Out the Rune] (expert) to scratch out the rune without allowing electricity to flow, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (2nd level; counteract DC 18) to counteract the rune

Ember Fox (PFS 2-14).name: Ember Fox (PFS 2-14)
Ember Fox (PFS 2-14).publicNotes: Ember foxes resemble their canid namesakes, save for the flames that make their fur and the tips of their long whiskers flicker and glow.

Empowered Blood (1-2).name: Empowered Blood (1-2)
Empowered Blood (1-2).descriptionHazard: Glowing red Daemonic runes blaze when blood falls on them.
Empowered Blood (1-2).disable: @Check[type:thievery|dc:18|name:Scratch Out Runes] (untrained) to scratch out enough runes to disrupt the magic or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (1st level; counteract DC 15) to counteract the runes.
Empowered Blood (1-2).reset: The hazard resets at the beginning of each round until it is disabled

Empowered Blood (3-4).name: Empowered Blood (3-4)
Empowered Blood (3-4).descriptionHazard: Glowing red Daemonic runes blaze when blood falls on them.

Explosive Monolith (3-4).name: Explosive Monolith (3-4)
Explosive Monolith (3-4).descriptionHazard: A burst of abyssal energy ignites the sap in a nearby bruorsivi, which explodes in a burst of fiery splinters.
Explosive Monolith (3-4).disable:
@Check[type:arcana|dc:17], @Check[type:occultism|dc:17], or @Check[type:religion|dc:17] to magically alter the runes, or @Check[type:thievery|dc:20] to physically alter them. A PC that can read Abyssal or Cyclops is better able to identify key runes, gaining a +1 circumstance bonus to these check (+2 if they speak both).

Each check requires two actions, and disabling the monolith requires three successful checks. A PC that critically succeeds earns two success. On a failed check, the attempting PC is exposed to the burning flames wreathing the monolith, taking @Damage[2d6[fire]] damage(@Check[type:reflex|dc:17|basic:true|name:Explosive Monolith]).
Explosive Monolith (3-4).routine:
(1 action) On the hazard's turn, randomly select a PC within 40 feet of the monolith. A tree near that PC explodes in a @Template[type:burst|distance:10], dealing @Damage[1d6[piercing],1d6[fire]]{1d6 piercing damage and 1d6 fire damage}. Each creature in the area must attempt a @Check[type:reflex|dc:17|name:Explosive Monolith|traits:damaging-effect] save.

Critical Success The creature takes no damage.

Success The creature takes half damage.

Failure The creature takes full damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} for 1 round.

Critical Failure The creature takes double damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Blinded} for 1 round.

@Check[type:arcana|dc:20], @Check[type:occultism|dc:20], or @Check[type:religion|dc:20] to magically alter the runes, or @Check[type:thievery|dc:23] to physically alter them. A PC that can read Abyssal or Cyclops is better able to identify key runes, gaining a +1 circumstance bonus to these check (+2 if they speak both).

Explosive Monolith (5-6).routine:

Famished Mimic.name: Famished Mimic
Famished Mimic.publicNotes:
Thought to be the result of a failed experiment meant to animate objects or a sinister alghollthu creation, mimics are clever monsters that can take the form of common manufactured objects. Mimics are ambush predators and voracious eaters, surprising their prey through their uncanny ability to mimic the form of common furniture and miscellany. They remain disguised until unsuspecting adventurers happen by, then they lash out in ambush.

Mimics possess complex alien minds, and while often cruel and self-serving, they also enjoy conversation with their prey from time to time. For unknown reasons, they are especially interested in humanoids. Mimics have a strong dislike for others of their kind and tend to live alone. A mimic can remain in its alternate form for an extremely long period of time, sometimes remaining disguised in a dungeon chamber for decades. Regardless of how long it waits, the mimic remains vigilant and alert, ready to strike at any moment.

Fence (PFS 2-00).name: Fence (PFS 2-00)
Fence (PFS 2-00).publicNotes:
The longer criminals hold on to stolen loot, the greater the chance they will get caught. Fences make themselves indispensable in the underworld by paying for stolen goods in order to resell them later, whether through a seemingly legitimate business or to a closed group of elite buyers.

Some criminals are the desperate who have no option but to break the law to survive, while others choose a life of crime for thrills, forming gangs or underworld guilds that specialize in certain illegal ventures.

Flames of Verakivhan (3-4).name: Flames of Verakivhan (3-4)
Flames of Verakivhan (3-4).descriptionHazard: The demon lord Urxehl manifests upon Golarion a small region of his Abyssal realm, filled with constantly burning forests lashed by fierce storms and unholy rain that only further feeds the flames. This is a mystical fire, fueled by the presence of Urxehl's minions. Any flames on the map emit concealing smoke in a 10-foot radius around the fire.
Flames of Verakivhan (3-4).disable: @Check[type:nature|dc:17] or @Check[type:performance|dc:17] (trained) to remind the Finadar forest of its true self; or @Check[type:religion|dc:17], @Check[type:occultism|dc:17], or @Check[type:demon-lore|dc:17]{Demon Lore}(trained) to disrupt the connection to the imposed realm and extinguish one of the five sections of flames on the map. These checks can only be attempted by creatures adjacent to the section, and each attempt takes 2 actions. An extinguished fire still emits concealing smoke for 1 additional round but is no longer hot enough to deal damage. A @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} spell or a spell with the water trait (2nd level; counteract DC 15) extinguishes a section of flames. If the PCs disable three of the five sections of the flames of Verakivhan, the hazard is too weakened to sustain itself, and the remaining flames disappear. If there are no demons or elementals remaining in the area, the hazard is automatically disabled.
Flames of Verakivhan (3-4).routine: (3 actions) Any creature within the flames takes @Damage[(1d6+3)[fire]] damage, and any creature adjacent to the flames takes @Damage[1d6[fire]] damage (@Check[type:reflex|dc:17|basic:true|name:Flames of Verakivhan|traits:fire] save). Additionally, the flames call down a fiery rain that deals @Damage[(1d6+3)[fire]] damage to a random PC within the planar overlay (@Check[type:reflex|dc:17|basic:true|name:Flames of Verakivhan|traits:fire] save). If any PCs attempted to disable the hazard that turn, the fiery rain chooses one of them as its target.

Flames of Verakivhan (5-6).name: Flames of Verakivhan (5-6)
Flames of Verakivhan (5-6).descriptionHazard: The demon lord Urxehl manifests upon Golarion a small region of his Abyssal realm, filled with constantly burning forests lashed by fierce storms and unholy rain that only further feeds the flames. This is a mystical fire, fueled by the presence of Urxehl's minions. Any flames on the map emit concealing smoke in a 10-foot radius around the fire.
Flames of Verakivhan (5-6).disable: @Check[type:nature|dc:20] or @Check[type:performance|dc:20] (trained) to remind the Finadar forest of its true self; or @Check[type:religion|dc:20], @Check[type:occultism|dc:20], or @Check[type:demon-lore|dc:20]{Demon Lore}(trained) to disrupt the connection to the imposed realm and extinguish one of the five sections of flames on the map. These checks can only be attempted by creatures adjacent to the section, and each attempt takes 2 actions. An extinguished fire still emits concealing smoke for 1 additional round but is no longer hot enough to deal damage. A @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} spell or a spell with the water trait (2nd level; counteract DC 17) extinguishes a section of flames. If the PCs disable three of the five sections of the flames of Verakivhan, the hazard is too weakened to sustain itself, and the remaining flames disappear. If there are no demons or elementals remaining in the area, the hazard is automatically disabled.
Flames of Verakivhan (5-6).routine: (3 actions) Any creature within the flames takes @Damage[(1d10+6)[fire]] damage, and any creature adjacent to the flames takes @Damage[1d10[fire]] damage (@Check[type:reflex|dc:20|basic:true|name:Flames of Verakivhan|traits:fire]). Additionally, the flames call down a fiery rain that deals @Damage[(1d10+6)[fire]] damage to a random PC within the planar overlay (@Check[type:reflex|dc:20|basic:true|name:Flames of Verakivhan|traits:fire] save). If any PCs attempted to disable the hazard that turn, the fiery rain chooses one of them as its target.

Flooding Monolith (3-4).name: Flooding Monolith (3-4)
Flooding Monolith (3-4).descriptionHazard: A surge of abyssal energy creates a powerful wave pushing away from the monolith.
Flooding Monolith (3-4).disable:
@Check[type:arcana|dc:18], @Check[type:occultism|dc:18], or @Check[type:religion|dc:18] to magically alter the runes, or @Check[type:thievery|dc:21] to physically alter them. A PC that can read Abyssal or Cyclops is better able to identify key runes, gaining a +1 circumstance bonus to these check (+2 if they speak both).

Each check requires two actions, and disabling the monolith requires three successful checks. A PC that critically succeeds earns two success. On a failed check, the attempting PC is exposed to the burning flames wreathing the monolith, taking @Damage[2d6[fire]] damage (@Check[type:reflex|dc:18|basic:true|name:Flooding Monolith] save).
Flooding Monolith (3-4).routine:
(1 action) On the hazard's turn it sends a wave of water along the fork of the river (North, South, or East) that contains the nearest PC. Any creature along that fork in or on the surface of the water must attempt a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:18|name:Flooding Monolith] save.

The monolith's guardians are accustomed to these surges and are immune to this effect.

Critical Success The creature takes advantage of the undertow after the surge to reposition themselves. The creature can Step, ignoring difficult terrain caused by the water.

Success The creature is unaffected.

Failure The creature is pushed 10 feet away from the monolith.

Critical Failure The creature is pushed 15 feet away from the monolith and knocked @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.

Flooding Monolith (5-6).name: Flooding Monolith (5-6)
Flooding Monolith (5-6).descriptionHazard: A surge of abyssal energy creates a powerful wave pushing away from the monolith.

A PC that can read Abyssal or Cyclops is better able to identify key runes, gaining a +1 circumstance bonus to these check (+2 if they speak both). Each check requires two actions, and disabling the monolith requires three successful checks. A PC that critically succeeds earns two success. On a failed check, the attempting PC is exposed to the burning flames wreathing the monolith, taking @Damage[2d6[fire]] damage (@Check[type:reflex|dc:22|basic:true] save).

The monolith's guardians are accustomed to these surges and are immune to this effect.

Success The creature is unaffected.

Failure The creature is pushed 10 feet away from the monolith.

Critical Failure The creature is pushed 15 feet away from the monolith and knocked @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.

Foretold Ruin (1-2).name: Foretold Ruin (1-2)
Foretold Ruin (1-2).descriptionHazard: Daemonic curses slither and crawl through malevolent runes carved in four stone pillars. HP is per-pillar.
Foretold Ruin (1-2).disable: @Check[type:thievery|dc:17|name:Disable Thievery] (trained) to scratch out a pillar's runes, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (1st level; counteract DC 15) to counteract a pillar's magic, or @Check[type:athletics|dc:18|name:Disable Athletics|traits:action:force-open]{Athletics (Force Open)} to push a pillar over. Disabling a pillar requires two actions. Disabling all four pillars or slaying Sezruth disables the trap
Foretold Ruin (1-2).routine:
Routine (4 actions) The trap loses 1 action each turn for each disabled pillar. On its initiative, the trap uses each action to afflict a different non-evil creature in the room with thirst. The creature must attempt a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:17|name:Foretold Ruin|traits:damaging-effect] save.

Critical Success The creature is temporarily immune to additional negative effects from the foretold ruin hazard's reaction for 24 hours. The hazard has no awareness of this immunity and continues to target this creature.

Success The creature is unaffected.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.HL2l2VRSaQHu9lUw]{Fatigued} until they drink water. If the creature was already fatigued, they take [[/r 1d6 #nonlethal mental]]{1d6 nonlethal mental damage}.

Critical Failure The creature is fatigued until they drink water and takes [[/r 1d6 #nonlethal mental]]{1d6 nonlethal mental damage}. If the creature was already fatigued, they instead take [[/r 2d6 #nonlethal mental]]{2d6 nonlethal mental damage}.

Foretold Ruin (3-4).name: Foretold Ruin (3-4)
Foretold Ruin (3-4).descriptionHazard: Daemonic curses slither and crawl through malevolent runes carved in four stone pillars. HP is per-pillar.

Disabling a pillar requires two actions. Disabling all four pillars or slaying Sezruth disables the trap
Foretold Ruin (3-4).routine:
Routine (4 actions) The trap loses 1 action each turn for each disabled pillar. On its initiative, the trap uses each action to afflict a different non-evil creature in the room with thirst. The creature must attempt a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:20|name:Foretold Ruin|traits:damaging-effect] save.

Critical Success The creature is temporarily immune to additional negative effects from the foretold ruin hazard's reaction for 24 hours. The hazard has no awareness of this immunity and continues to target this creature.

Success The creature is unaffected.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.HL2l2VRSaQHu9lUw]{Fatigued} until they drink water. If the creature was already fatigued, they take [[/r 1d6 #nonlethal mental]]{1d6 nonlethal mental damage}.

Critical Failure The creature is fatigued until they drink water and takes [[/r 1d6 #nonlethal mental]]{1d6 nonlethal mental damage}. If the creature was already fatigued, they instead take [[/r 2d6 #nonlethal mental]]{2d6 nonlethal mental damage}.

Hands of Slow Death.name: Hands of Slow Death
Hands of Slow Death.descriptionHazard: A pile of dust and bone meal, several inches deep and 10 feet across on each side, blocks the tunnel to the surface. It is suffused with the despair of the slowly dying, and summons vengeful skeletal hands to hunt down anyone who dares attempt to leave the area.
Hands of Slow Death.disable:
@Check[type:religion|dc:15|name:Administer Burial Rites|traits:haunt] (trained) to speak the proper burial rites, @Check[type:occultism|dc:15|name:Exorcise Spirits|traits:haunt] (trained) to exorcise the lingering souls, or @Check[type:intimidation|dc:17|name:Scare Away Spirits|traits:haunt] to scare the fearful souls away.

These actions have the verbal trait. Each check to disable the hazard requires 2 actions, and two total successes are required to disable the haunt.
Hands of Slow Death.reset: The haunt deactivates if no creatures remain within 30 feet but resets immediately thereafter unless disabled. If tthe haunt is disabled, it resets after 24 hours.
Hands of Slow Death.routine: (1 action) Spectral hands grasp at creatures in the area. Each creature within 30 feet of the dust pile takes @Damage[1d4[void]] damage (@Check[type:will|dc:17|basic:true|name:Grasping Hands] save; creatures that critically fail this saving throw are @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for 1 round).

Hidden Bog.name: Hidden Bog
Hidden Bog.descriptionHazard: This section of grass-strewn ground hides a pool of sticky mud 10 feet across.
Hidden Bog.disable: 2 @Check[type:crafting|dc:15|name:Create a makeshift plank|traits:environmental] or 2 @Check[type:thievery|dc:18|name:Create a makeshift plank|traits:environmental] to create a makeshift plank across the hidden bog; creatures can then traverse the hazard's area without stepping into the mud.
Hidden Bog.reset: Creatures can still step into the mud after the trap is revealed, but the area containing the mud is obvious.

Hunting Spider (PFS 2-18).name: Hunting Spider (PFS 2-18)
Hunting Spider (PFS 2-18).publicNotes:
Hunting spiders are the most common type of giant spider, though not the largest.

Few everyday vermin inspire as much dread as the infamous spider.

Ice Slick.name: Ice Slick
Ice Slick.descriptionHazard: A sheer slick of ice causes anyone other than Ssalarn who attempts to cross it to slip and fall.
Ice Slick.disable: 2 @Check[type:athletics|dc:18|name:Break Ice Slick|traits:environmental] to break the ice and roughen its surface

Iverri (3-4).name: Iverri (3-4)
Iverri (3-4).allSavesBonus: +1 status to all saves vs. magic

Iverri (5-6).name: Iverri (5-6)
Iverri (5-6).allSavesBonus: +1 status to all saves vs. magic

Jinkin (PFS 2-00).name: Jinkin (PFS 2-00)
Jinkin (PFS 2-00).publicNotes:
Jinkins are sadistic tinkers who steal and sabotage items and take great pride in their power to curse precious objects. They hold grudges and create convoluted plans for revenge whenever they feel slighted, such as when a creature dares to remove one of their curses. Rarely content to wreak simple mayhem, jinkins also take immense pleasure in torture and murder, though they prefer to lead victims into traps designed to capture or incapacitate rather than kill outright. Deep pits are favorites, since victims who survive the fall face a slow death from starvation and thirst. Jinkins enjoy gathering at the edge of pits to mock, tease, and torment.

Gremlins are cruel fey tricksters and saboteurs who have fully acclimated to life on the Material Plane, finding distinct niches for their inventive destructiveness. All gremlins delight in ruining or breaking things, whether it's something physical like a device or vehicle or something intangible such as an alliance or relationship. A gremlin's greatest joy is watching the collapse of complex creations, preferably after the lightest and slightest, carefully targeted push from the gremlin. Gremlins tend to denigrate, bully, or even slaughter their lesser kin, particularly mitflits, whom gremlins (and many others) derisively call "mites."

Joyful Planar Nixie.name: Joyful Planar Nixie
Joyful Planar Nixie.allSavesBonus: +1 status to all saves vs. magic

Kobold Warrior (PFS 2-11).name: Kobold Warrior (PFS 2-11)
Kobold Warrior (PFS 2-11).publicNotes:
The typical kobold trains with agile weaponry, favoring the light pick for its use in crafting new tunnels to expand their domains through underground reaches. Kobolds are capable of landing sneaky strikes against unsuspecting foes but are just as quick to scamper off to safety when they don't, as a group, outnumber their enemies at least two to one.

Kobolds are small, reptilian humanoids who carry physical similarities to true dragons. They lurk in dark spaces, usually tunnels and mines beneath the earth, in either warrens of their own design or complexes discovered and colonized after the original builders have moved on. Though kobolds are far more pragmatic than they are courageous, they use every inch of their cunning to even the playing field between themselves and other, stronger creatures. They attack from the darkness and at range, and kobold artificers and engineers master the art of simple but effective traps, which they use to protect their lairs. Kobolds are skilled at working together by necessity, and they often set up ambushes or hit-and-run assaults that allow them to do the most damage possible without being harmed in return.

Kobolds are diligent and hardworking creatures, though they often turn these virtues toward selfish ends. While some kobolds live in communal collectives that maintain neutral relations with the creatures around them, they can be easily swayed into serving malevolent powers or megalomaniac leaders. This is in part due to kobolds' innate pragmatism, as they would rather concede to servitude than risk being killed, but it is also in part due to a reverence for the power that kobolds generally lack. Dragons in particular are viewed with a deferential awe, and kobolds eagerly offer their services to such mighty and glorious creatures when they can. While kobolds may scheme against other leaders, especially those that control them via subjugation, dragons are usually viewed with adoration, no matter how brutal they might be to their kobold minions.

Lion (PFS 2-13).name: Lion (PFS 2-13)
Lion (PFS 2-13).publicNotes:
Lions are cooperative hunters, ambushing dangerous prey in groups of lionesses that work in tandem to trap and kill their prey. Male lions are typically larger, with long manes, and when they hunt, they tend to do so on their own.

Few predators of the natural world can match the cat's talent for stalking and stealth.

Mechanical Jaws (1-2).name: Mechanical Jaws (1-2)
Mechanical Jaws (1-2).descriptionHazard: Mechanical jaws bolted to the stone beneath a camouflaged floor tile.

Mechanical Jaws (3-4).name: Mechanical Jaws (3-4)
Mechanical Jaws (3-4).descriptionHazard: Mechanical jaws bolted to the stone beneath a camouflaged floor tile.

Mushroom Ring (1-2).name: Mushroom Ring (1-2)
Mushroom Ring (1-2).descriptionHazard: This mushroom ring forms a portal to the First World, allowing the Thorned Monarch's reinforcements into the Material Plane. When the PCs approach, a creature emerges. Creatures continue to emerge until the mushroom ring is disabled. Disabling the mushroom ring also causes any creatures that have emerged to disappear.
Mushroom Ring (1-2).disable: @Check[type:thievery|dc:15|traits:action:disable-a-device] (trained) or @Check[type:nature|dc:18] to rearrange the mushrooms to disrupt the portal (two actions); three successes are required to disable the portal
Mushroom Ring (1-2).routine: (1 action) A @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.pathfinder-bestiary.Actor.jnmUcTs4hn1c5bz9]{Pugwampi} emerges from the mushroom ring and defends it. All pugwampis use the mushroom ring's initiative.

Mushroom Ring (3-4).name: Mushroom Ring (3-4)
Mushroom Ring (3-4).descriptionHazard: This mushroom ring forms a portal to the First World, allowing the Thorned Monarch's reinforcements into the Material Plane. When the PCs approach, a creature emerges. Creatures continue to emerge until the mushroom ring is disabled. Disabling the mushroom ring also causes any creatures that have emerged to disappear.
Mushroom Ring (3-4).disable: @Check[type:thievery|dc:22|traits:action:disable-a-device] (trained) or @Check[type:nature|dc:22] to rearrange the mushrooms to disrupt the portal (two actions) or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (2nd level, counteract DC 20) to counteract the magical properties; three successes are required to disable the portal
Mushroom Ring (3-4).routine: (1 action) A @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.pathfinder-bestiary-2.Actor.bpwaqRoO1wYo15T5]{Nuglub} emerges from the mushroom ring and defends it. All nuglubs use the mushroom ring's initiative.

Mushroom Ring (5-6).name: Mushroom Ring (5-6)
Mushroom Ring (5-6).descriptionHazard: This mushroom ring forms a portal to the First World, allowing the Thorned Monarch's reinforcements into the Material Plane. When the PCs approach, a creature emerges. Creatures continue to emerge until the mushroom ring is disabled. Disabling the mushroom ring also causes any creatures that have emerged to disappear.
Mushroom Ring (5-6).disable: @Check[type:thievery|dc:21|traits:action:disable-a-device] (expert) or @Check[type:nature|dc:25] (trained) to rearrange the mushrooms to disrupt the portal (two actions) or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (3rd level, counteract DC 23) to counteract the magical properties; three successes are required to disable the portal
Mushroom Ring (5-6).routine: (1 action) A @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.pathfinder-bestiary-2.Actor.xIvv8vKBa0YsTEzt]{Korred} emerges from the mushroom ring and defends it. All korreds use the mushroom ring's initiative.

Mushroom Ring (7-8).descriptionHazard: This mushroom ring forms a portal to the First World, allowing the Thorned Monarch's reinforcements into the Material Plane. When the PCs approach, a creature emerges. Creatures continue to emerge until the mushroom ring is disabled. Disabling the mushroom ring also causes any creatures that have emerged to disappear.
Mushroom Ring (7-8).disable: @Check[type:thievery|dc:24|traits:action:disable-a-device] (expert) or @Check[type:nature|dc:28] (expert) to rearrange the mushrooms to disrupt the portal (two actions) or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (4th level, counteract DC 26) to counteract the magical properties; three successes are required to disable the portal
Mushroom Ring (7-8).routine: (1 action) A @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.pathfinder-bestiary.Actor.8uXLbKKzxN5O0ZhM]{Elananx} emerges from the mushroom ring and defends it. All elananxes use the mushroom ring's initiative.

Mutated Trollhound.name: Mutated Trollhound
Mutated Trollhound.publicNotes:
Trollhounds are squat, slavering beasts akin to trolls in canine form. Requiring vast quantities of meat to fuel their regenerative metabolisms, packs of wild trollhounds prowl the foothills of regions where trolls dwell, their voracious hunger driving them to slaughter and consume any prey they encounter. In some regions, trolls breed trollhounds as pets, utilizing the trollhounds' keen sense of smell to aid in the hunt.

Covered in fetid, weeping sores, trollhounds are carriers of a debilitating contagion known as bloodfire fever. Creatures that contract the disease through the bite of a trollhound experience deep internal pain, as if their blood were on fire. Additional symptoms include loss of muscle coordination, pus-filled blisters, and overall lethargy and fatigue. Other than suffering from skin irritation, both trolls and trollhounds are immune to the major effects of the disease.

Trollhounds are fearless on the hunt and in combat, relying on their ability to regenerate to carry them through. Not even the threat of fire is enough to repel them, as the beasts don't recognize the danger it represents. Nevertheless, fire is one of the most effective tools in combating trollhounds; canny hunters know to burn every last remnant of a supposedly slain trollhound, for their regenerative powers are potent indeed.

While trolls themselves have had great success in domesticating, training, and even befriending trollhounds, the same cannot be said for other would-be masters. Whether impeded by constant exposure to trollhounds' diseased slobber, their ravenous hunger that never seems to be fully sated, or simply their foul personality and quick-to-bite temperament, most attempts to use trollhounds in place of more reliable guardians end in pain, misery, and a pack of feral trollhounds escaping into the hinterlands. Left to their own devices, a pack of escaped trollhounds can breed relatively quickly, and it can take less than a year for a small pack to multiply into a significant threat to the countryside. Best to leave the trollhounds to the trolls, as they say!

Nuglub (PFS 2-00).name: Nuglub (PFS 2-00)
Nuglub (PFS 2-00).publicNotes:
The "towering" hunchbacked nuglubs are among the largest gremlins, though they're not quite three feet tall. Nuglubs have three glowing blue eyes and black, oily hair on their head and back that covers them like a cloak. Nuglubs enjoy killing with a glee that other gremlins reserve for sabotage. Indeed, they spend long hours preparing ambushes for unwary travelers or plotting the murders of sleeping villagers. Though less technically inclined than their kin, nuglubs do enjoy building traps. They delight in stealthily constructing traps in places their victims consider familiar, such as front doors and the floors around beds. If someone else gets blamed for the mayhem the nuglub creates, all the better.

In combat, nuglubs focus on targets wearing metal armor. Some attribute this to envy on the part of the nuglubs, who find it difficult to fit armor on their twisted bodies. Nuglubs are particularly talented at causing those nearby to stumble over them and fall prone. Once an enemy falls to the ground, all the nuglubs descend upon the target, biting and scratching until nothing remains.

Nuglubs rarely gather in groups larger than half a dozen, as quarrels often lead to violence and cannibalism. A lone nuglub who bullies a group of smaller gremlins is more likely to get their way, and thus less likely to attack their allies.

Ogre Spider (PFS 2-18).name: Ogre Spider (PFS 2-18)
Ogre Spider (PFS 2-18).publicNotes: These terrifying creatures grow as large as elephants. The placement of their eyes above their wide mandibles evokes the grimacing visage of an ogre's leer. Ogres themselves find the appearance of ogre spider faces simultaneously amusing and adorable, but in most cases, ogres' attempts to keep these spiders as pets result in dead ogres and well-fed spiders.

Pixie (PFS 2-00).name: Pixie (PFS 2-00)
Pixie (PFS 2-00).publicNotes:
Insatiably curious, overly excitable, and just a bit puckish, pixies are wanderers and tricksters who use their pixie dust to create all sorts of whimsical situations, as well as to defend themselves. Other creatures often have trouble understanding a pixie's rapid, rambling way of speaking.

Elusive, flighty, and ebullient, sprites are what many villagers first imagine when they hear the terms "fey" or "fairy." While their dispositions vary from the benevolent grig to the trickster pixie, all sprites share a connection to magic and diminutive size. This family of fey shares its name with its slightest and most populous member, the common sprite.
Pixie (PFS 2-00).allSavesBonus: +1 status to all saves vs. magic

Plague Zombie (PFS 2-15).name: Plague Zombie (PFS 2-15)
Plague Zombie (PFS 2-15).publicNotes:
Plague zombies are infested with hideous contagions.

A zombie's only desire is to consume the living. Unthinking and ever-shambling harbingers of death, zombies stop only when they're destroyed.

Planar Cracks (5-6).name: Planar Cracks (5-6)
Planar Cracks (5-6).descriptionHazard: The cracks scintillate and shift between the elemental planes, leaking perilous energy with each shift.
Planar Cracks (5-6).disable: @Check[type:thievery|dc:24|name:Assemble a Seal|traits:environmental,magical] (trained) twice to assemble a seal using objects strongly grounded to the Material Plane, @Check[type:arcana|dc:22|name:Invoke Incantations|traits:environmental,magical] (trained) twice to invoke incantations to seal the cracks, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (3rd level, counteract DC 20) to counteract the cracks.
Planar Cracks (5-6).routine:
(1 action) A surge of energy strikes a random non-mephit creature in the foyer. Roll [[/r 1d4]] to determine the element of the energy surge.

1-Energy from the Plane of Air: the creature takes @Damage[2d8[electricity]] damage (@Check[type:reflex|dc:22|basic:true|name:Planar Cracks|traits:air,electricity] save); on a failure, the creature is pushed back 10 feet toward the entryway. The hazard gains the air and electricity traits for this round.

2-Energy from the Plane of Earth: the creature takes @Damage[2d8[bludgeoning]] damage (@Check[type:reflex|dc:22|basic:true|name:Planar Cracks|traits:earth] save); on a failed save, the creature is knocked @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}. The hazard gains the earth trait for this round.

3-Energy from the Plane of Fire: the creature takes @Damage[(2d8+7)[fire]] damage (@Check[type:reflex|dc:22|basic:true|name:Planar Cracks|traits:fire] save). The hazard gains the fire trait for this round.

4-Energy from the Plane of Water: the creature takes @Damage[2d8[cold]] damage (@Check[type:reflex|dc:22|basic:true|name:Planar Cracks|traits:water,cold] save); on a failed save, the creature's lungs fill with water, making them @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}. The hazard gains the cold and water traits for this round.

Planar Cracks (7-8).descriptionHazard: The cracks scintillate and shift between the elemental planes, leaking perilous energy with each shift.
Planar Cracks (7-8).disable: @Check[type:thievery|dc:28|name:Assemble a Seal|traits:environmental,magical] (expert) twice to assemble a seal using objects strongly grounded to the Material Plane, @Check[type:arcana|dc:26|name:Invoke Incantations|traits:environmental,magical] (trained) twice to invoke incantations to seal the cracks, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (4th level, counteract DC 22) to counteract the cracks.
Planar Cracks (7-8).routine:
(1 action) A surge of energy strikes a random non-mephit creature in the foyer. Roll [[/r 1d4]] to determine the element of the energy surge.

1-Energy from the Plane of Air: the creature takes @Damage[(2d10+3)[electricity]] damage (@Check[type:reflex|dc:25|basic:true|name:Planar Cracks|traits:air,electricity] save); on a failure, the creature is pushed back 10 feet toward the entryway. The hazard gains the air and electricity traits for this round.

2-Energy from the Plane of Earth: the creature takes @Damage[(2d10+3)[bludgeoning]] damage (@Check[type:reflex|dc:25|basic:true|name:Planar Cracks|traits:earth] save); on a failed save, the creature is knocked @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}. The hazard gains the earth trait for this round.

3-Energy from the Plane of Fire: the creature takes @Damage[(2d10+9)[fire]] damage (@Check[type:reflex|dc:25|basic:true|name:Planar Cracks|traits:fire] save). The hazard gains the fire trait for this round.

4-Energy from the Plane of Water: the creature takes @Damage[(2d10+3)[cold]] damage (@Check[type:reflex|dc:25|basic:true|name:Planar Cracks|traits:water,cold] save); on a failed save, the creature's lungs fill with water, making them @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2}. The hazard gains the cold and water traits for this round.

Planar Nixie.allSavesBonus: +1 status to all saves vs. magic

Pressurized Bottle (1-2).name: Pressurized Bottle (1-2)
Pressurized Bottle (1-2).descriptionHazard: One of the potions has decayed, putting it under immense pressure. Its contents have become poisonous. When handled improperly, the bottle bursts, sending glass shards flying everywhere.
Pressurized Bottle (1-2).disable: @Check[type:thievery|dc:17|name:Pressurized Bottle|traits:mechanical,trap] (trained) to carefully place the bottle under a bucket or bowl.

Pressurized Bottle (3-4).name: Pressurized Bottle (3-4)
Pressurized Bottle (3-4).descriptionHazard: One of the potions has decayed, putting it under immense pressure. Its contents have become poisonous. When handled improperly, the bottle bursts, sending glass shards flying everywhere.

Quickling (PFS 2-00).name: Quickling (PFS 2-00)
Quickling (PFS 2-00).publicNotes:
Few creatures can match a quickling's speed. These malicious fey creatures delight in striking with blinding speed and accuracy, racing in to stab and slash at foes before scampering away for cover with maddening- even frightening-swiftness. Stories of people simply doubling over, bleeding from what appear to be spontaneously opening wounds, are often eyewitness accounts of quickling attacks.

Quicklings actively hate the "slow-paced dullards" they encounter every day, delighting in inflicting suffering and pain on creatures they deem too sluggish to matter. While they are related to kinder fey such as brownies and pixies, quicklings care only for their own merriment. They see their own cruel pranks as the height of humor and have full confidence that their speed and invisibility will keep them safe from harm. They occasionally form gangs of up to a dozen individuals, although the group usually devolves very quickly into mayhem, as they inevitably perform increasingly deadly pranks against each other.

Relive the Rending (1-2).name: Relive the Rending (1-2)
Relive the Rending (1-2).descriptionHazard: The room shakes violently, as it did during the Rending, and the spirits of dozens of dwarves make a mad dash for safety, their terror palpable.
Relive the Rending (1-2).disable: @Check[type:diplomacy|dc:18|name:Calm the Spirits|traits:unique,complex,haunt], @Check[type:intimidation|dc:18|name:Calm the Spirits|traits:unique,complex,haunt], or @Check[type:religion|dc:18|name:Calm the Spirits|traits:unique,complex,haunt] to calm the panicked spirits, or @Check[type:athletics|dc:20|name:Wrestle Spirits into Order|traits:unique,complex,haunt] to wrestle them into a semblance of order. Two successful checks are required to deactivate the haunt, and each attempt requires two actions.
Relive the Rending (1-2).reset: Unless deactivated, the haunt deactivates 1 minute after all creatures leave the area but resets immediately thereafter. If deactivated, the haunt resets after 24 hours.
Relive the Rending (1-2).routine:
(1 action) Phantom dwarves trample toward the exit, dealing @Damage[(1d10+4)[bludgeoning]] damage to each living creature in the area (@Check[type:reflex|dc:20|basic:true|name:Trampled by Spirits|traits:complex,haunt,unique] save). On a critical failure, a creature is also knocked @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.

A creature that attempts to Stand after being inside the haunt's area must succeed at a @Check[type:flat|dc:11] check or else get knocked back down by the trampling spirits.

Relive the Rending (3-4).name: Relive the Rending (3-4)
Relive the Rending (3-4).descriptionHazard: The room shakes violently, as it did during the Rending, and the spirits of dozens of dwarves make a mad dash for safety, their terror palpable.
Relive the Rending (3-4).disable: @Check[type:diplomacy|dc:18|name:Calm the Spirits|traits:unique,complex,haunt], @Check[type:intimidation|dc:18|name:Calm the Spirits|traits:unique,complex,haunt], or @Check[type:religion|dc:18|name:Calm the Spirits|traits:unique,complex,haunt] to calm the panicked spirits, or @Check[type:athletics|dc:20|name:Wrestle Spirits into Order|traits:unique,complex,haunt] to wrestle them into a semblance of order. Two successful checks are required to deactivate the haunt, and each attempt requires two actions.
Relive the Rending (3-4).reset: Unless deactivated, the haunt deactivates 1 minute after all creatures leave the area but resets immediately thereafter. If deactivated, the haunt resets after 24 hours.
Relive the Rending (3-4).routine:
(1 action) Phantom dwarves trample toward the exit, dealing @Damage[(2d8+5)[bludgeoning]] damage to each living creature in the area (@Check[type:reflex|dc:23|basic:true|name:Trampled by Spirits|traits:complex,haunt,unique] save). On a critical failure, a creature is also knocked @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.

A creature that attempts to Stand after being inside the haunt's area must succeed at a @Check[type:flat|dc:11] check or else get knocked back down by the trampling spirits.

Saddleback Bunyip.name: Saddleback Bunyip
Saddleback Bunyip.publicNotes:
Bunyips are dangerous aquatic predators that resemble a cross between a shark and a seal. Found in freshwater inlets or saltwater coves worldwide, bunyips hunt where prey is plentiful, often to the consternation of coastal residents and fisherfolk.

Despite their outlandish appearance and tendency to defend their territory with loud, bellowing roars that echo for great distances, bunyips are very rarely sighted by humanoids, leaving many to question their existence. For hundreds of years, bunyips were widely regarded as nothing more than folk tales, and even now that their existence as a species has been proven, the existence of any particular bunyip in a local area is often met with heavy skepticism. While their limited shapechanging abilities are no doubt a significant part of the reason for this air of mystery, another major factor is that the aquatic creatures rarely hunt humanoids, preferring to eat smaller animals. Most bunyips avoid human contact, except when one wanders too close to their den or favorite hunting spot, at which point the territorial bunyip attacks with swift and terrible ferocity. Many scholars agree that a large number of unexplained disappearances near coastal areas are the result of unreported bunyip aggression.

In some ports, bunyips have learned that delicious prizes can be had from the chum and garbage discarded by fishing boats and merchant vessels. They lurk close to the shore and carefully choose their victims, plucking them off docks and small boats. These bunyips are particularly careful to keep their true forms hidden, but this does little to dull rumors of monster-infested waters.

Scorched Cavern Troll.name: Scorched Cavern Troll
Scorched Cavern Troll.publicNotes:
Insatiable scavengers stalking the eternal gloom of the Darklands, cavern trolls consume all in their path-even rocks and minerals when more nourishing sustenance is scarce. These rocky goliaths can tunnel through stone with their iron-sharp claws.

Cavern trolls rarely venture to the surface world, for they have a debilitating vulnerability to sunlight that petrifies them on sustained contact. Unlike common trolls, cavern trolls can regenerate wounds dealt by fire. The crystalline nature of their skin, however, permits sonic attacks to neutralize their signature regeneration.

As cavern trolls age, their flinty skin becomes studded with small crystals and stones of various composition. Paragons of their kind have toothy maws replete with large, crystalline fangs. A typical cavern troll stands 14 feet in height and weighs about 2,000 pounds.

Sinkhole.descriptionHazard: An assortment of leaves and loose dirt cover a sudden drop in elevation.
Sinkhole.disable: @Check[type:nature|dc:12|name:Uncover Sinkhole|traits:environmental] to remove the covering foliage

Sliding Statue (1-2).descriptionHazard: With a rumble, this statue of a former Pathfinder slides across the schoolyard. Its legs pump up and down as it advances.
Sliding Statue (1-2).disable: @Check[type:athletics|dc:20|name:Hold Back Statue|traits:complex,hazard,magical,trap] to hold it back, @Check[type:crafting|dc:17|name:Break Statue|traits:complex,hazard,magical,trap] (trained) to break the statue by exploiting a flaw, @Check[type:occultism|dc:16|name:Dispel Planar Energies|traits:complex,hazard,magical,trap] (trained) to dispel the planar energies.
Sliding Statue (1-2).routine: (3 actions) The trap uses its three actions for its Trample activity.

Each attempt to Disable the hazard requires two actions, and each successful check to Disable removes one action from the hazard's routine.

Stranded Melody (5-6).routine: (2 actions) For each action in the routine, the melody makes a solid refrain Strike against one creature in its area. This trap doesn't take a multiple attack penalty.

The Scholar of Sorts (1-2).name: The Scholar of Sorts (1-2)
The Scholar of Sorts (1-2).publicNotes:
Akizendris gnaw at sources of knowledge and lore, gleefully corrupting and altering them to vex scholars and sages across the planes with contradictions and untruths. These proteans appear as cackling, serpentine creatures with elongated crocodilian faces, luminous eyes, and arms that vanish at the elbows into swirling clouds of runes before reforming into solid talons.

Akizendris amuse themselves by rearranging or deleting texts, placing insulting acrostics in poetic verses, and penning crude insults upon title pages. Libraries in such places as Heaven, Axis, and Hell are especially keen to avoid such contamination, knowing that their records are choice targets for every akizendri in existence.

The Scholar of Sorts (3-4).name: The Scholar of Sorts (3-4)
The Scholar of Sorts (3-4).publicNotes:
Akizendris gnaw at sources of knowledge and lore, gleefully corrupting and altering them to vex scholars and sages across the planes with contradictions and untruths. These proteans appear as cackling, serpentine creatures with elongated crocodilian faces, luminous eyes, and arms that vanish at the elbows into swirling clouds of runes before reforming into solid talons.

Akizendris amuse themselves by rearranging or deleting texts, placing insulting acrostics in poetic verses, and penning crude insults upon title pages. Libraries in such places as Heaven, Axis, and Hell are especially keen to avoid such contamination, knowing that their records are choice targets for every akizendri in existence.

Tough Small Opossum.name: Tough Small Opossum
Tough Small Opossum.allSavesBonus: +2 circumstance to all saves vs. disease

Twigjack (PFS 2-08).name: Twigjack (PFS 2-08)
Twigjack (PFS 2-08).publicNotes:
Maladjusted forest denizens, twigjacks form from the cruel and prankish combination of fey and the very woods in which they reside. A twigjack's body is made up of prickly brambles woven with vines. Shaggy, mossy growth, not unlike hair, tops a twigjack's head. Its mouth is just a canyon of splintered and broken sticks bisecting its face. Leaves and sprigs of new growth randomly sprout from the creature's body. Many dense forests on Golarion have at least a handful of twigjacks living in the undergrowth.

While truculent and violent, twigjacks care deeply for what they consider to be their forests. These creatures harass outsiders who delve deep into their wooded domains, forcing back even the most determined explorers, foresters, and travelers, especially when those intruders cut roads through the forest. However, they are not terribly territorial when it comes to other forest creatures. When sylvan creatures, especially fey, rally against an outside threat, twigjacks in the area eagerly arrive to fight, even if they were not invited.

Less seasoned travelers who encounter twigjacks in their canopied homes often mistake them for leshys, a tendency that frustrates twigjacks, as they have a low opinion of such creatures. More broadly, twigjacks resent being considered mere animated plants at all. Rather, they embrace their fey heritage-often to a foolish end. Twigjacks go out of their way to ingratiate themselves to the fey creatures they live among. Several popular comic songs weave the tale of a twigjack attempting to woo a powerful and graceful dryad, only to be comically disgraced after many loutish attempts. Many fey seem embarrassed by these strange cousins, but some spriggans, quicklings, and redcaps harness the twigjacks' violent urges and disruptive behavior for their own purposes.

While twigjacks are fey, and as such are often found in the First World, it's somewhat curious that those twigjacks who find religion only rarely turn to the Eldest of the First World. Instead, twigjacks tend to worship false deities of their own design: figures spotted in tangles of tree branches, clots of undergrowth, or other hidden nooks in the natural world. These religions are always highly localized, and while these faiths do not support clerics, they often inspire zealous crusades against non-fey.

Unkillable Zombie Shambler.name: Unkillable Zombie Shambler
Unkillable Zombie Shambler.publicNotes:
A zombie shambler is a slow-moving horror dangerous in larger groups.

A zombie's only desire is to consume the living. Unthinking and ever-shambling harbingers of death, zombies stop only when they're destroyed.

Unstable Ice.name: Unstable Ice
Unstable Ice.descriptionHazard: The ice here is fractured due to the warming weather conditions and the inexorable flow of the ocean water below.
Unstable Ice.disable: 2 @Check[type:athletics|dc:19|name:Move Ice|traits:environmental] to move the ice sheets into a more stable position

Weak Lion.name: Weak Lion
Weak Lion.publicNotes:
Lions are cooperative hunters, ambushing dangerous prey in groups of lionesses that work in tandem to trap and kill their prey. Male lions are typically larger, with long manes, and when they hunt, they tend to do so on their own.

Few predators of the natural world can match the cat's talent for stalking and stealth.

Weak Mist Stalker.name: Weak Mist Stalker
Weak Mist Stalker.publicNotes:
The tentacled mist stalker shrouds itself in a cloak of mist through which its single, never-blinking eye can see with clarity, allowing it an advantage when stalking its prey.

Water elementals that become infused with cold or mist have increased mobility in regions outside of bodies of water.

Weak Mudwretch.name: Weak Mudwretch
Weak Mudwretch.publicNotes:
In its resting form, a mudwretch looks like a large puddle of thick, dark mud, heaped at the center in a slightly drier patch of loam. When a living creature approaches, though, the mudwretch lurches upward, piling its muddy flesh upon itself to form a roughly humanoid shape, often in vague mockery of the approaching creature's general form in cases where the creature is a humanoid itself.

Mudwretches possess a low level of intellect, and while they do not form societies or cultures of their own, they are attracted to ruins or abandoned settlements. They have little need to eat, but without a constant source of moisture, a mudwretch dries out, suffering from low throbbing aches until it can resaturate. Often, blood from living creatures has to do-a dried mudwretch is more dangerous to intruders than one that's comfortably wallowing on a river bank.

Weak Sea Devil Scout.name: Weak Sea Devil Scout
Weak Sea Devil Scout.publicNotes:
Scouts, among the lowliest of sea devils, ply the inky waters of the ocean in search of aquatic prey, tread ashore to gauge landborne threats, or charge into battle with the advance forces of a greater sea devil war party.

Sea devils are horrid, amphibious humanoids who lurk in Golarion's oceans and crawl ashore to steal away victims beneath the veil of darkness. When an entire fishing village disappears overnight, sea devils are the first suspects.

Far from mindless monstrosities, sea devils are terribly intelligent, with a cunning limited only by their strict adherence to hierarchy. They call themselves "sahuagin" but have wholly embraced their enemies' name for their kind as their own. Their cultural militancy enables sea devils to act in concert to perform grand acts of sabotage, marauding, and pillaging, and only the strongest (and most conniving) members of the tribe make it to the top of the social ladder. For all their discipline, however, sea devils are widely known to snap into murderous frenzies at the scent of blood. Even the best-laid plans can fall apart when a sea devil breaks ranks to revel in the spilled blood of their victims, an indulgence that can quickly cause a chain reaction of bloodthirsty ecstasy throughout an entire raiding party. For this reason, sea devils typically capture landborne quarry using nets and ropes, dragging them to the depths of the sea before making even a single incision.

Among sea devil society, individuals are rewarded based on their performance during hunts and shore excursions, with rebels and outliers quickly culled from the ranks. Every pup is given a fair chance, however, and even the lowest-born sea devil can strive for the rank of commander, general, or perhaps even king or queen. Sea devils in positions of leadership tend to be among the largest, most violent, and most calculating of their kind, and fully realized sea devils are skilled warriors capable of capturing entire villages on their own. The most powerful sea devils are mighty kings and queens who coordinate the activity of lesser sea devils across territories spanning leagues, foiling attempts at their positions via manufactured blood feuds and wars against their numerous enemies ashore and underwater.

Yeth Warbeast.name: Yeth Warbeast
Yeth Warbeast.publicNotes:
Wicked canine creatures who live for the thrill of the hunt, yeth hounds often serve evil masters as guardians and trackers. Yeth hounds resemble lean, sleek dogs with overlarge ears and narrow paws that can tread on air as easily as the ground. Despite their canine appearance, yeth hounds are remarkably intelligent, although they rarely display this intelligence except when devising intricate tactics to ensnare their quarry. Their eerie bays echo across the countryside when they are engaged in a hunt, and they particularly enjoy baying to frighten and disorient intelligent creatures. Yeth hound packs can number as many as a dozen members, each working in uncanny communion with its packmates to corner and kill their prey. Yeth hounds like to drag their victims back to their lairs to eat at their leisure, so these lairs often contain discarded treasures from the hounds' previous meals.

Yeth hounds despise two things: sunlight and other canines. They hunt only at night if they can, often breaking off their hunt at dawn to retreat to a subterranean lair or den, no matter how close they had come to catching their prey. Yeth hounds usually attack wargs, wolves, and similar creatures on sight, working to drive larger or more powerful canines from their hunting areas when then can't simply overpower and kill them.

Evil rangers, bestial demons, and wicked cults are frequently gifted yeth hound servants by fiendish patrons. Such hounds often serve as spies and are quick to turn against those who fail to advance the patrons' wicked aims. The cult of Lamashtu, in particular, is fond of using yeth hounds as temple guardians.

Ygracix.name: Ygracix
Ygracix.publicNotes:
Imps are infiltrators and corruptors who, despite their diminutive stature, are more than capable of subtly influencing a weak-willed individual into performing increasingly evil acts over time. An imp will often agree to serve a mortal and act docile and loyal in a long-term plot to eventually damn its master's soul to Hell. Imps are born directly from Hell itself, rather than from mortal souls, and thus they serve outside the usual diabolic hierarchy, granting them leeway to pursue their specialties. Despite standing a mere 2-feet tall, imps can be vicious combatants, flying out of reach and turning invisible to escape should the odds turn against them.

Masters of corruption and architects of conquest, devils seek both to tempt mortal life to join in their pursuit of all things profane and to spread tyranny throughout all worlds. The temptations they offer mortals range from great powers granted by the signing of an infernal contract to twisted favors following a whispered pledge to a diabolic patron, or any number of even subtler exchanges. Those who succumb to these temptations find themselves consigned to an afterlife of endless torment in the pits of Hell, wherein the only hope of escape lies in the chance of being promoted to become a devil in the infernal ranks. Every devil has a specific role to play in the upkeep of the remorseless bureaucratic machine that is Hell, from soldiers and scholars to inquisitors, lawyers, judges, and executioners. Lowly lemures and imps perform subservient labor to more powerful and specialized devils, such as contract devils and erinyes, while the greatest pit fiends command entire infernal armies.

Young Ahuizotl.name: Young Ahuizotl
Young Ahuizotl.publicNotes:
The ahuizotl is a vicious, semi-aquatic predator that resembles a hideous cross between a badger and an otter, with disturbingly web-fingered paws supplemented by a fifth hand at the end of a long, serpentine tail. A clever and stealthy hunter, the ahuizotl lures unwary prey to their doom by mimicking the cries of people in distress.

The ahuizotl's macabre habit of feeding on a victim's eyes, fingernails, and teeth leaves the corpses of its kills uniquely mutilated. Some say the creatures consider these body parts delicacies, while others insist ahuizotls collect them as tribute to a powerful but unknown entity.

The fact that an ahuizotl does not eat the actual flesh of its victims, instead depositing their savaged and waterlogged corpses in locations where the remains are sure to be found by friends or family, points to a third and perhaps more likely possibility-the ahuizotl simply enjoys using its violent dietary quirks to spread fear and despair.

An ahuizotl walks on all fours, but its hands are capable of manipulating simple tools and other objects. Ahuizotls have roughly mustelid features and an extra membrane covering their eyes, giving their eyes a dull color suggestive of cataracts and somewhat blunting the creature's vision.

Yet despite their bestial appearance, ahuizotls are nearly as intelligent as the average human, and wiser than most. Although they don't form societies of their own, they have been known to ally with violent cults or conclaves of monsters, and even to found small shrines and temples to sinister deities.

The cult of Charon, the horseman of Death, is particularly popular among certain ahuizotls, who look forward to an afterlife spent wallowing in the waters of the River Styx.
